headline: Poilievre to run for Alberta seat after MP Damien Kurek agrees to step down | CBC News
context: Conservative MP Damien Kurek says he will resign his Alberta seat so Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre can run in a forthcoming byelection.

annotations.paragraph: Peter Zimonjic  · CBC News
annotations.reason: This is an author byline and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Conservative MP Damien Kurek says he will resign his Alberta seat so Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre can run in a forthcoming byelection.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides the main news about Kurek resigning for Poilievre to run.

annotations.paragraph: "Although it will be hard to temporarily step away from this role, in this region I love and have always called home, the mandate given to me is one that clearly states that change is needed," he said in a statement on Friday.

annotations.paragraph: "Offering this seat to our party leader is an important step in that process."
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes the significance of the decision to offer the seat to Poilievre.

annotations.paragraph: Kurek first won the seat of Battle River-Crowfoot in 2019. Kurek was re-elected on Monday with almost 82 per cent of the vote.
annotations.reason: This provides background on Kurek's electoral history, relevant to understanding his decision.

annotations.paragraph: "It is with humility and appreciation that I have accepted Damien Kurek's offer to resign his seat in Battle River-Crowfoot so that I can work to earn the support of citizens there to serve them in Parliament," Poilievre said in a statement posted on X.

annotations.paragraph: Prime Minister Mark Carney, meanwhile, said Friday that he will call that byelection as soon as possible to ensure Poilievre has the chance to quickly return to the House of Commons.

annotations.paragraph: Poilievre lost his Ottawa-area seat of Carleton, a riding he held for more than 20 years, by five percentage points, losing to Liberal candidate Bruce Fanjoy.

annotations.paragraph: "I've already indicated to Mr. Poilievre that … I will ensure that it happens as soon as possible. No games, nothing," Carney said in his first news conference as an elected official on Friday.
